name: GMC-802
keyboard: 2 detachable controllers with knob and button
coprocessor: Paddle size left, Paddle size right, Ball angle, Ball speed, Sound on/off, Power on/off
description:
This one is one the last pong built so it's quite complete and offers everything a player needs to play pong in good conditions.

The use of the Motorola M-588135 chipset makes it possible to choose a different bat size for each player. The system has even an on/off sound switch (quite useful)!

This pong is the same system as the more famous Nintendo Color TV Game-15. The Motorola M-588315 chipset is indeed a clone of the Mitsubishi Electric M58816P chipset used in the Nintendo system. Games are the same.

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said : <br><br> ''The computer which carried away America"<br><br> ''With its portable computers, Compaq became world number two on the market of the 16 bits computers. With a turnover of 240 million dollars in one year and a half, this young company established in Houston obtained the growth rate record of the American economic history." </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br>  ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional picture for the Channel F System II.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advertising for the MZ 1500 (with the Quick Disk drive) in a Japanese magazine.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> When you buy, lease or rent word processing equipment from AM Jacquard Systems, you get our total commitment, now and in the future, that assures the successful installation and operation of your AMtext word processing system. <br><br> To support that commitment, we have offices in over 100 cities throughout North America staffed with skilled professionals ready to meet your neads with planning, training. supplies, and service... <br><br> ...The AMtext 100 is a true shared resource, multifunction information system capable of supporting multiple work stations and peripherals simultaneously. <br><br> The Amtext 425 and 425A are powerful stand-alone work stations with a full-page video display <br><br> The AMtext 225 is a low-cost system that turns electric typewriters into flexible text editors. <br><br> The AMtext product line includes a complete selection of peripheral devices, including telecommunications, an optical character reader. magnetic card reader, phototypesetters, daisy wheel printers. high-speed line and matrix printers, as well as mass storage on floppy and hard disk drive units.  <br><br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
